message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: An Overview of Recent Advances in Coordinated Control of Multiple Autonomous Surface Vehicles
Paper Abstract: Autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs) are marine vessels capable of performing various marine operations without a crew in a variety of cluttered and hostile water/ocean environments. For complex missions, there are increasing needs for deploying a fleet of ASVs instead of a single one to complete difficult tasks. Cooperative operations with a fleet of ASVs offer great advantages with enhanced capability and efficacy. Despite various application potentials, coordinated motion control of ASVs pose great challenges due to the multiplicity of ASVs, complexity of intravehicle interactions and fleet formation with collision avoidance requirements, and scarcity of communication bandwidths in sea environments. Coordinated control of multiple ASVs has received considerable attention in the last decade. This article provides an overview of recent advances in coordinated control of multiple ASVs. First, some challenging issues and scenarios in motion control of ASVs are presented. Next, coordinated control architecture and methods of multiple ASVs are briefly discussed. Then, recent results on trajectory-guided, path-guided, and target-guided coordinated control of multiple ASVs are reviewed in detail. Finally, several theoretical and technical issues are suggested to direct future investigations including network-based coordination, event-triggered coordination, collision-free coordination, optimization-based coordination, data-driven coordination of ASVs, and task-region-oriented coordination of multiple ASVs and autonomous underwater vehicles.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Autonomous surface vehicles"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned surface vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_surface_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned surface vehicles of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_surface_vehicles_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"UAPS20 Unmanned AutoPilot System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAPS20_Unmanned_AutoPilot_System"},{"title":"Hilairy Hartnett - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilairy_Hartnett"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned surface vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_surface_vehicles"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about autonomous surface vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned surface vehicle (USV), also called a drone boat, drone ship or sea drone, is a boat or ship that operates on the surface of the water without a crew.(no content)USVs operate with various levels of autonomy, from remote control to fully autonomous surface vehicles (ASV).

## Applications

Autonomous surface vehicles have diverse applications:

- **Hydrographic Surveying**: USVs are a powerful tool for commercial hydrographic survey, and using a small USV in parallel to traditional survey vessels can double survey coverage and reduce time on-site.

- **Scientific Research**: Saildrones are a type of uncrewed surface vehicle used primarily in oceans for data collection and are wind and solar powered with science sensors and navigational instruments.

- **Urban Use**: In 2021, the world's first urban autonomous vessels, Roboats, were deployed in the canals of Amsterdam and could carry up to five people, collect waste, deliver goods, and monitor the environment.

- **Military Applications**: In 2024, TCB Marlin entered service in the Turkish Naval Forces as the first armed USV.

## Fleet Management Context

The search results primarily returned information about fleet management systems rather than formation control specifically. Fleet management software (FMS) is a software platform used for fleet management that enables businesses to manage and coordinate their commercial vehicles through a single interface, with the software's purpose being to improve operational efficiency, enhance safety, and ensure regulatory compliance by processing data collected from in-vehicle telematics devices.

## Naval Fleet Formations

The results also included historical information about naval fleet formations. Only one formation allows the ships of the same fleet to satisfy fully certain conditions of combat effectiveness—the line ahead formation (column).

## Formation Flight (Aviation Context)

Additionally, the results included information about formation control in aviation. Formation flying is the flight of multiple objects in coordination, which occurs in nature among flying and gliding animals, and is also conducted in human aviation, often in military aviation and air shows.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Trajectory planning robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Kinodynamic planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinodynamic_planning"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Motion control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_control"},{"title":"Automated planning and scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_planning_and_scheduling"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_A*"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Robot kinematics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_kinematics"}]

Here are the results of the web search for "Trajectory planning robotics":

## Overview

Trajectory planning has a wide variety of applications in robotics, including industry, manipulation, walking, path-planning, and aerospace. It's a critical component of robotic systems across different types of applications.

## Key Applications

Open-chain robotic manipulators require trajectory optimization, such as a 7-joint robotic arm where trajectory optimization can be used to avoid obstacles or minimize torque in the joints. Trajectory optimization is often used to compute trajectories for quadrotor helicopters.

In autonomous vehicles, trajectory planning is applied to cars and trucks that must respect acceleration, steering, and velocity limits; in aerial robotics for quadrotors and unmanned aerial vehicles; in manipulation for robotic arms; and in legged locomotion for footstep and trajectory planning.

## Kinodynamic Planning

In robotics and motion planning, kinodynamic planning is a class of problems where velocity, acceleration, and force/torque bounds must be satisfied, together with kinematic constraints such as avoiding obstacles.

## Modern Approaches

Recent mixed-integer optimization approaches have demonstrated the ability to find globally optimal solutions with proven constraint satisfaction, and modern optimization-based planners can achieve execution times several orders of magnitude faster than sampling-based methods while maintaining strict adherence to kinodynamic constraints.

I've performed a web search for "Motion control robotics." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Motion control is a sub-field of automation, encompassing the systems or sub-systems involved in moving parts of machines in a controlled manner.(no content)Control of robotic manipulators is included in the field of motion control because most of robotic manipulators are driven by electrical servo motors and the key objective is the control of motion.

## System Components

A motion control system contains a motion controller, which calculates and controls the mechanical trajectories (motion profile) an actuator must follow through motion planning and employs feedback to make control corrections in closed loop systems.(no content)The main components involved typically include a motion controller, an energy amplifier, and one or more prime movers or actuators.

## Applications

Motion control is widely used in the packaging, printing, textile, semiconductor production, and assembly industries.(no content)Motion control systems are extensively used in a variety of fields for automation purposes, including precision engineering, micromanufacturing, biotechnology, and nanotechnology.

## Control Types

Motion control may be open loop or closed loop. In open loop systems, the controller sends a command through the amplifier to the prime mover or actuator without knowing if the desired motion was achieved. In closed loop systems, feedback sensors such as encoders, resolvers or Hall effect devices return the position or velocity of the actuator to the motion controller.

I've performed a web search for "Motion control robotics." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Motion control is a sub-field of automation, encompassing the systems or sub-systems involved in moving parts of machines in a controlled manner.(no content)Control of robotic manipulators is included in the field of motion control because most of robotic manipulators are driven by electrical servo motors and the key objective is the control of motion.

## System Components

A motion control system contains a motion controller, which calculates and controls the mechanical trajectories (motion profile) an actuator must follow through motion planning and employs feedback to make control corrections in closed loop systems.(no content)The main components involved typically include a motion controller, an energy amplifier, and one or more prime movers or actuators.

## Applications

Motion control is widely used in the packaging, printing, textile, semiconductor production, and assembly industries.(no content)Motion control systems are extensively used in a variety of fields for automation purposes, including precision engineering, micromanufacturing, biotechnology, and nanotechnology.

## Control Types

Motion control may be open loop or closed loop. In open loop systems, the controller sends a command through the amplifier to the prime mover or actuator without knowing if the desired motion was achieved. In closed loop systems, feedback sensors such as encoders, resolvers or Hall effect devices return the position or velocity of the actuator to the motion controller.

Web search results for query: "Cooperative control robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Cobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobot"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_collaboration"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IISc_Guidance,_Control_and_Decision_Systems_Laboratory"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Collaborative Control Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_Control_Theory"},{"title":"Human–robot interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_interaction"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotic_manipulation"},{"title":"Robot control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_control"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Universal Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Robots"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of cooperative control robotics:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Cooperative robotics involves research in swarm robotics, multi-robot systems, and cooperative robotics with applications to tasks such as cooperative transportation, robotic formations, cooperative search/rescue, and odor source localization.

## Cooperative vs. Collaborative Control

It's important to distinguish between cooperation and collaboration in robotics:

Cooperation involves all the aspects of coordination as well as a resource-sharing dimension to support goal achievement, and commonly exhibits a division of labor component among all participants. In contrast, collaboration involves sharing of information, resources and responsibilities among all parties to jointly plan, implement, and assess the set of activities required to achieve a common goal.

## Adaptive Collaborative Control

Adaptive collaborative control is a decision-making approach that enables humans and robots to work together as partners rather than in traditional master-slave relationships, allowing autonomous agents and human operators to collaborate as peers, sharing decision-making responsibilities to accomplish common goals.

## Multi-Agent Systems

A multi-agent system is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Human-Robot Cooperation

In industrial settings, collaborative robots (cobots) physically interact with humans in a shared workspace to complete tasks such as collaborative manipulation or object handovers.

Links: [{"title":"Traffic collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Carrier-sense multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carrier-sense_multiple_access_with_collision_avoidance"},{"title":"Airborne collision avoidance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airborne_collision_avoidance_system"},{"title":"Automatic Ground Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_Ground_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Multiple access with collision avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_Access_with_Collision_Avoidance"},{"title":"Maritime Collision Avoidance System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maritime_Collision_Avoidance_System"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (networking) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(networking)"},{"title":"Collision avoidance in transportation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_in_transportation"},{"title":"Collision avoidance (spacecraft) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collision_avoidance_(spacecraft)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about collision avoidance:

## Overview

In transportation, collision avoidance is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

## Applications Across Different Domains

**Automotive**: A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)Once an impending collision is detected, these systems provide a warning to the driver. When the collision becomes imminent, they can take action autonomously without any driver input (by braking or steering or both).

**Aviation**: A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision (MAC) between aircraft. It monitors the airspace around an aircraft for other aircraft equipped with a corresponding active transponder, independent of air traffic control, and warns pilots of the presence of other transponder-equipped aircraft which may present a threat of MAC.

**Maritime**: Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness. These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence, to issue navigational alerts, assess risks, or initiate corrective actions.

**Spacecraft**: Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

**Networking**: In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

Links: [{"title":"Quantum optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_optimization_algorithms"},{"title":"Mathematical optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_optimization"},{"title":"Spiral optimization algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_optimization_algorithm"},{"title":"Ant colony optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_colony_optimization_algorithms"},{"title":"Category:Optimization algorithms and methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Optimization_algorithms_and_methods"},{"title":"Rider optimization algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rider_optimization_algorithm"},{"title":"Global optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_optimization"},{"title":"Template talk:Optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Optimization_algorithms"},{"title":"Local search (optimization) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_search_(optimization)"},{"title":"Combinatorial optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combinatorial_optimization"}]

## Web Search Results: Optimization Algorithms

I've completed a web search for "Optimization algorithms." Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Overview
Mathematical optimization is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives.(no content)It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.

### Types of Optimization Algorithms

The search results reveal several major categories of optimization algorithms:

1. **Local Search Methods**: Local search is a heuristic method for solving computationally hard optimization problems.(no content)Local search algorithms move from solution to solution in the space of candidate solutions by applying local changes, until a solution deemed optimal is found or a time bound is elapsed.

2. **Swarm-Based Algorithms**: The ant colony optimization algorithm (ACO) is a probabilistic technique for solving computational problems that can be reduced to finding good paths through graphs.

3. **Combinatorial Optimization**: Combinatorial optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.(no content)Typical combinatorial optimization problems are the travelling salesman problem ("TSP"), the minimum spanning tree problem ("MST"), and the knapsack problem.

4. **Global Optimization**: Global optimization is a branch of operations research, applied mathematics, and numerical analysis that attempts to find the global minimum or maximum of a function or a set of functions on a given set.

### Optimization Methods
Common approaches to global optimization problems, where multiple local extrema may be present include evolutionary algorithms, Bayesian optimization and simulated annealing.

## Web Search Results: Optimization Algorithms

I've completed a web search for "Optimization algorithms." Here's a summary of the key findings:

### Overview
Mathematical optimization is the selection of a best element, with regard to some criteria, from some set of available alternatives.(no content)It is generally divided into two subfields: discrete optimization and continuous optimization.

### Types of Optimization Algorithms

The search results reveal several major categories of optimization algorithms:

1. **Local Search Methods**: Local search is a heuristic method for solving computationally hard optimization problems.(no content)Local search algorithms move from solution to solution in the space of candidate solutions by applying local changes, until a solution deemed optimal is found or a time bound is elapsed.

2. **Swarm-Based Algorithms**: The ant colony optimization algorithm (ACO) is a probabilistic technique for solving computational problems that can be reduced to finding good paths through graphs.

3. **Combinatorial Optimization**: Combinatorial optimization is a subfield of mathematical optimization that consists of finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects, where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a discrete set.(no content)Typical combinatorial optimization problems are the travelling salesman problem ("TSP"), the minimum spanning tree problem ("MST"), and the knapsack problem.

4. **Global Optimization**: Global optimization is a branch of operations research, applied mathematics, and numerical analysis that attempts to find the global minimum or maximum of a function or a set of functions on a given set.

### Optimization Methods
Common approaches to global optimization problems, where multiple local extrema may be present include evolutionary algorithms, Bayesian optimization and simulated annealing.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous underwater vehicles"

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Autonomous underwater vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Autonomous_underwater_vehicles"},{"title":"Vityaz-D Autonomous Underwater Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vityaz-D_Autonomous_Underwater_Vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"AUV-150 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AUV-150"},{"title":"Maya AUV India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_AUV_India"},{"title":"Explorer AUV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explorer_AUV"},{"title":"RoboSub - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboSub"},{"title":"Seaglider - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seaglider"},{"title":"Sentry (AUV) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentry_(AUV)"}]

I've completed a web search on autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). Here are the key findings:

## What are Autonomous Underwater Vehicles?

An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs constitute part of a larger group of undersea systems known as unmanned underwater vehicles, which includes non-autonomous remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs) that are controlled and powered from the surface by an operator via an umbilical or remote control.

## History and Development

The first AUV was developed at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington as early as 1957 by Stan Murphy, Bob Francois and later on, Terry Ewart.(no content)The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

## Sensors and Navigation

AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean, with typical sensors including compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Since radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

## Power Systems

Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

## Applications

Autonomous underwater vehicles have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, such as Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Links: [{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Path-planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Path-planning&redirect=no"},{"title":"Planning Alternative Tomorrows with Hope - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Alternative_Tomorrows_with_Hope"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*#:~:text=It makes assumptions about the,robot then follows the path."},{"title":"Graphical path method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphical_path_method"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Flight planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flight_planning"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

I've completed a web search for "Path planning". Here are the key results:

## Definition and Overview

Path planning, also known as motion planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves an object from source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Types and Approaches

There are several major approaches to path planning:

1. **Any-Angle Path Planning**: These are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing turns in the path to have any angle.

2. **Grid-Based Approaches**: Traditional grid-based approaches produce paths whose heading changes are constrained to multiples of a given base angle, often resulting in suboptimal paths. Any-angle path planning approaches find shorter paths by propagating information along grid edges without constraining paths to grid edges.

3. **Real-Time Path Planning**: This consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real-time changes in the environment, including everything from primitive algorithms that stop a robot when it approaches an obstacle to more complex algorithms that continuously take in information from surroundings and create plans to avoid obstacles.

4. **Sampling-Based Algorithms**: These represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations, sampling N configurations and retaining those in free space as milestones, then constructing a roadmap that connects two milestones if the line segment between them is completely in free space.

## Applications

Any-angle path planning is useful for robot navigation and real-time strategy games where more optimal paths are desirable.(no content)This ability to find an optimal path also plays an important role in other fields such as video games and gene sequencing.

I've completed the web search for "Machine learning data-driven". Here are the key findings:

## Machine Learning and Data-Driven Approaches

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.(no content)Data-driven modelling (DDM) refers to the overarching paradigm of using historical data in conjunction with advanced computational techniques, including machine learning and artificial intelligence, to create models that can reveal underlying trends, patterns, and, in some cases, make predictions.

### Connection Between the Two Fields

Machine learning, a subfield of artificial intelligence, is closely related to data-driven modelling as it also focuses on using historical data to create models that can make predictions and identify patterns. In fact, many data-driven models incorporate machine learning techniques, such as regression, classification, and clustering algorithms, to process and analyse data.

### Applications

These models have found applications in various fields, including economics, customer relations management, financial services, medicine, and the military, among others.

### Modern Context

In response to the challenges of big data, the relatively new field of data science uses machine learning (and other artificial intelligence) methods that allow for efficient applications of analytic methods to big data.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [pending] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Now let me edit the triples_output.json file with all the entities I found. Based on my research, here are the key entities from the paper that map to Wikipedia articles:

1. **Unmanned surface vehicle** - task/concept (ASV is a type of USV)
2. **Motion control** - method/concept
3. **Formation flying** - concept (relevant to fleet formation)
4. **Collision avoidance system** - method/concept
5. **Motion planning** - method/concept
6. **Autonomous underwater vehicle** - task/concept
7. **Multi-agent system** - concept (relevant to coordinated control)
8. **Mathematical optimization** - method/concept (for optimization-based coordination)
9. **Machine learning** - method/concept (for data-driven coordination)

For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

## Summary

I have successfully analyzed the paper "An Overview of Recent Advances in Coordinated Control of Multiple Autonomous Surface Vehicles" and completed all extraction tasks:

**Paper Classification**: **Survey** - This is a literature review paper that provides an overview of recent advances and reviews existing approaches, rather than proposing novel contributions.

**Key Entities Extracted** (9 triples):

1. **Unmanned surface vehicle** - The primary domain (autonomous marine vessels)
2. **Motion control** - Core control methodology for vehicle coordination
3. **Motion planning** - Trajectory and path planning techniques
4. **Collision avoidance system** - Safety requirements for multi-vehicle coordination
5. **Formation flying** - Concept for fleet formation control
6. **Autonomous underwater vehicle** - Related system for underwater coordination
7. **Multi-agent system** - Theoretical framework for multi-vehicle systems
8. **Mathematical optimization** - Foundation for optimization-based coordination
9. **Machine learning** - Technology for data-driven coordination approaches

All triples have been properly classified with entity types (task/method/concept), relations (uses), and linked to relevant Wikipedia articles. The validation script confirms all checks passed successfully.
